_exec_summary.SummaryText:

	(6)	a list of people to contact for further information on the plan.  

Actions to be taken by Miami Plant personnel have been extracted from the plan and summarized for easy reference during emergencies and have been posted in the Miami Plant.

8.2.2  Coordination of the Emergency Plans with Offsite Agencies

	The Miami Plant EAP has been provided to and discussed with the LEPC and the fire department (including the hazardous material [HAZMAT] team).  The Miami Plant H.R./Safety/Environmental Coordinator is responsible for providing any additional information that those organizations request.  The agencies are offered the opportunity to participate in our annual drills and any other emergency-related training that is appropriate.  We have provided MSDS¿s and other chemical-specific information for them and the two closest emergency medical facilities.  The Miami Plant H.R./Safety/Environmental Coordinator is responsible for maintaining an ongoing relationship with these organizations and either participates in each LEPC meeting or sends another Miami Plant representative.

8.2.3  Emergency Response Training for Visitors and Contract Employees

	Flexible Foam provides contractors with enough information regarding the EAP and applicable emergency response procedures for contract employees to respond to emergencies (i.e., report the emergency and/or evacuate the Miami Plant) in a safe manner.  Each contractor is responsible for documenting that each contract employee understands his or her role in an emergency.

	All incidental contractors and visitors are either accompanied by Flexible Foam employees or provided with a copy of the evacuation procedure.

8.2.4  Emergency Drills

	Flexible Foam conducts emergency evacuation drills as required to comply with 
regulatory requirements to (1) evaluate the EAP, (2) help ensure that personnel are properly 
trained, and (3) rehearse coordination with outside agencies.

Employees at the Miami Plant, as well as local emergency response agencies, participate in emergency response activities at the Miami Plant to protect the public, environment, employees, contractors, and other Miami Plant personnel in the event of a fire, explosion, vapor release, and/or liquid spill from the Miami Plant.  However, the facility is not used for treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste.  Therefore, the Miami Plant is presently covered under OSHA¿s Emergency Action Plan 29 CFR 1910.38(a), OSHA¿s HAZWOPER regulation 29 CFR 1910.120(q), and EPA¿s  RMP Emergency Response rule 40 CFR 68.95.  Flexible Foam has developed and implemented a written emergency response plan that complies with these regulatory requirements.

	The Miami Plant Emergency Response Program (ERP) has the following features:

	¿	Development of the Emergency Action Plan (EAP) ¿ Miami Plant and Corporate personnel developed and maintain a plan that defines Flexible Foam employee actions during various types of emergencies.  The plan is reviewed periodically and amended to keep it current

	¿	EAP content ¿ The EAP and associated procedures are directed at handling: 

		(1)	small chemical releases, 
		(2)	small incipient fires that can be easily extinguished, 
		(3)	personnel injuries and illnesses requiring first aid or emergency medical treatment, 
		(4)	weather-related emergencies

		For major fires, large hazardous chemical releases, and/or explosions, the EAP addresses: 

		(1)	rapid assessment of the emergency,
		(2)	notification of the public and appropriate offsite emergency response agencies, 
		(3)	containment of a fire or release from a safe distance, 
		(4)	employee and/or public evacuation, and 
		(5)	site security and control

 
		The EAP also addresses the use of emergency response equipment as well as the inspection, testing, and maintenance of such equipment.  The contents of the EAP are periodically reviewed and updated to reflect changes at the facility or to

address any concerns expressed by the public or emergency responders.  Employees, the local emergency planning committee, and emergency responders are informed of any changes in the EAP resulting from the review

	¿	Emergency Response Training ¿ The Miami Plant ensures that all employees are trained in applicable EAP procedures.  Selected operations and maintenance employees receive first responder operations level training and Miami Plant management receives on-scene incident commander training that meets the regulatory training requirements of HAZWOPER 29 CFR 1910.120(q), and EAP 29 CFR 1910.38(a).  Both groups receive annual refresher training that is coordinated using a site-specific Incident Command System (ICS).  Employees who do not directly participate in emergency response activities, visitors, and all contract employees receive annual training on the EAP.  Employees and contract employees are retrained when the EAP changes, prior to implementation of the changes

	¿	Emergency drills ¿ The Miami Plant routinely conducts emergency drills in conjunction with offsite emergency response agencies to help ensure that employees, contractors, and the public will react appropriately to true emergency situations.  Following emergency drills, Miami Plant management and offsite emergency response participants critique the performance of all personnel and alter the plan and/or training to address any perceived deficiencies

	The H.R./Safety/Environmental Coordinator implements and maintains the ERP Program.  An ERP Committee, under the direction of the Plant Manager and the H.R./Safety/Environmental Coordinator, develops the program and reviews all proposed alterations to the program.  All other Miami Plant personnel are responsible for understanding the emergency procedures, properly responding to emergencies, and alerting their supervisors to any problems with the plan.

	The RMP Coordinator supports the efforts associated with this program (as well as other RMP progr

ams).  The RMP Coordinator updates and distributes this program description and coordinates the activities involved in this program with those of other RMP programs at the Miami Plant.

	The following sections of this chapter describe the ERP Program in detail.  For each activity, the roles of key organizations and/or staff members are described.  These responsibilities are summarized in Appendix 8A.  Appendix 8B summarizes locations of referenced documents/records and lists the people responsible for maintaining that information.



8.2.1  Emergency Action Plan Development

Flexible Foam Products developed and revise the EAP and other procedures associated with emergency response.  The committee reviews regulatory and company requirements to (1) evaluate existing Miami Plant emergency procedures, (2) identify existing practices that need to be documented with written procedures, and (3) define new practices, procedures, and training requirements that are necessary to meet Flexible Foam¿s ERP objectives.

	Flexible Foam Products, Inc. developed the EAP to address: 

	(1)	small chemical releases, 
	(2)	small incipient fires that can be easily extinguished, 
	(3)	personnel injuries and illness requiring first aid or emergency medical treatment, and 
	(4)	weather-related emergencies.  

	The Miami Plant does not have a fire brigade.  Therefore, for major fires, large hazardous chemical releases, and/or explosions, the emergency response procedures address: 

	(1)	rapid assessment of the emergency,
	(2)	notification of the public and appropriate offsite emergency response agencies,
	(3)	containment of a fire or a release from a safe distance, 
	(4)	employee and/or public evacuation, and 
	(5)	site security and control.  

	The EAP also contains: 

	(1)	a list of emergency equipment and its location, 
	(2)	spill and PPE decontamination procedures, 
	(3)	emergency notification phone numbers, 
	(4)	plot plans that identify escape routes and shelter-in-place locations, 
	(5
